A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an epimorphism if it is surjective.

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is finite if $B$ is a finite $A$-module under $\varphi$. This is also referred to as $B$ being finite over $A$ or, if $\varphi$ is an inclusion homomorphism, that the extension $A \hookrightarrow B$ is finite.
Does the concept of a/an Ring Epimorphism need to be defined for a definition of a/an Finite Ring Homomorphism to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a Finite Ring Homomorphism involves a ring homomorphism where the target ring $B$ is a finite module over the source ring $A$ via the homomorphism. This definition focuses on the algebraic structure and the finiteness condition of the module generated by the image of the homomorphism in the target ring.

On the other hand, a Ring Epimorphism is defined as a surjective ring homomorphism. This concept emphasizes the surjectivity of the homomorphism, ensuring that every element of the target ring $R'$ is the image of some element in the source ring $R$.

The definition of a Finite Ring Homomorphism does not inherently require the homomorphism to be surjective; it only requires that the target ring be finite as a module over the source ring. Therefore, the concept of a Ring Epimorphism, which focuses on surjectivity, is not necessary for the definition of a Finite Ring Homomorphism to make sense. The finiteness condition can be satisfied without the homomorphism being surjective, as it pertains to the module structure rather than the mapping being onto.
